titlestmt.subtitle: A Guide to his Papers at the Indiana University Archives
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Alison Reynolds

change.item: Batch update to change repository name, subject links, preferred citation, and user restrictions.

did.abstract: Peter Fraenkel began his career with Indiana University in 1943 as an undergraduate student majoring in physics and mathematics, graduating in 1946. He later worked in the offices of President Herman B Wells from 1948 to 1962 and President John W. Ryan from 1974 to 1985. Beginning in 1985, he served as Director of Overseas Projects Development for the Office of International Programs until his retirement in 1988. In between his university positions, he worked as a Program Associate for the Ford Foundation's Latin American-Caribbean division. At both institutions, his work emphasized international education and the development and evaluation of higher education programs. This collection contains correspondence and administrative files from Fraenkel's positions with Indiana University and the Ford Foundation, materials relating to his overseas travel and involvement with professional associations, program files for Ford Foundation grants in Spain, and speeches written or delivered by Fraenkel.
did.langmaterial: Materials are in English, Spanish, and German

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Select files closed to researchers, but may be accessed upon request after archivist's review.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Peter Adolf Fraenkel was born in Germany in 1923, but spent most of his childhood in Bolivia, where his family moved to escape Nazi persecution. Fraenkel showed a propensity for languages, becoming fluent in German, Spanish, and English by the age of 15. He graduated from the American Institute at La Paz, the equivalent of an American high school, in 1942. As a teenager in 1941, Fraenkel met Indiana University President Herman B Wells when he was assigned as Wells's guide and interpreter during Wells's visit to South America on an educational mission. The two quickly became friends and remained in contact with each other after Wells departed South America. Eventually, Wells recruited Fraenkel to come to Indiana, first as a student, and later as an employee.

Fraenkel began his career at Indiana University in 1943 as an undergraduate student majoring in physics and mathematics. In 1946, he left Indiana to begin graduate work in physics at Harvard University. When Wells was appointed educational advisor for the American Military Government in Germany in 1947, he took Fraenkel with him as a research assistant. Soon after, Fraenkel abandoned his graduate studies in order to return to Indiana University. He first served as a research assistant in the President's Office in 1948, and eventually became Assistant to the President in 1951. He held this position until 1962, when he left Indiana University for the Ford Foundation.

During his early years with Indiana University, Fraenkel was involved in many university committees and programs, including the Board of Aeons, the Cosmopolitan Club, and the Faculty Associate program for the Tower Center residential hall. As a Faculty Associate, he served as a liaison between the students at Tower Center and administrators, and was known for planning dinners and social outings to the opera for his students.

He was also involved in several professional organizations supporting higher education. Most prominently, he served as a consultant for the North Central Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools (NCA) from approximately 1957 to 1961. In this role, he traveled to different universities to review their administrative practices and help evaluate them for accreditation.

In addition to his work within the university, Fraenkel was also very active in promoting university relations both in the United States and abroad. He received a Carnegie grant in 1957 to visit liberal arts colleges around the country in order to improve relations with other universities and share ideas about the administration of higher education. In 1961, he worked with the University of Notre Dame to establish an all-Hoosier Peace Corps unit in Chile. The following year, he traveled to Peru for an administrative review of Indiana University's Junior Year in Peru program and represented Indiana University at the Inter-American Seminar on Educational Travel and Exchanges Program in Colombia.

In 1962, Fraenkel took a position with the Ford Foundation in New York City as a Program Associate in the Overseas Development Program of the Foundation's Latin American-Caribbean division. In this position, he worked with new and existing grants that focused on strengthening educational and governmental institutions within the countries in these regions. From 1964 to 1969, Fraenkel lived in Peru in order to establish and direct a Ford Foundation field office and manage grants in that country. He led a similar project in Spain from 1970 to 1974, where he also established a field office and worked with Spanish educators and officials to improve advanced training and create opportunities for Spaniards to conduct research in the United States and Europe. Throughout his career with the Ford Foundation, Fraenkel worked in Peru, Colombia, Bolivia, Ecuador, and Spain. Most of his work revolved around administering educational reform programs and grants within these countries.

After working with the Ford Foundation for twelve years, Fraenkel returned to Indiana University in 1974 as a special assistant to University President John W. Ryan. Although employed by Indiana University, Fraenkel's position was funded by a grant from the Ford Foundation. As part of this position, he traveled to Spain to serve as a full-time consultant to the Spanish Minister of Education and Science in Madrid. One of his major responsibilities was to assist in the implementation of the educational aspects of the United States-Spanish Agreement of Friendship. He held this position until 1976. After this grant-funded position expired, Fraenkel moved back to Bloomington and resumed his career at Indiana University as an advisor in the President's Office. In 1978, he took over as Assistant to President Ryan after the death of Paul Klinge, the previous assistant.

Although no longer working in a position requiring overseas travel, Fraenkel was frequently asked to serve as a freelance consultant for educational reform programs in Spanish-speaking countries and maintained his contacts abroad. In 1981, he returned to Spain to assist a university in establishing extension centers in smaller nearby towns.

Upon President Ryan's retirement in 1985, Frankel became Director of Overseas Projects Development for the Office of International Programs. He retired from this position in 1988 after a career at Indiana University spanning 40 years and 5 university presidencies.
Peter Fraenkel passed away in 2007 at the age of 83 after a struggle with Alzheimer's disease.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is arranged into six series: Biographical, Ford Foundation, Professional, Correspondence, Speeches, and Subject files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Biographical series (1940-1976) is arranged chronologically. It contains personal information about Fraenkel, including his diaries, personal directories, college and graduate school information, his photograph collections, and photographs of himself and his friends and family.
The Ford Foundation series (1960-1981) contains three subseries: General, Education Programs in Spain, and Correspondence.

The General subseries (1966-1980) is arranged alphabetically and contains materials about the Ford Foundation, largely during Fraenkel's time of employment with the agency. It includes administrative files and reports about the Ford Foundation, files about individual countries, and materials related to Fraenkel's international travel for the organization.

The Education Programs in Spain subseries (1965-1981) is arranged alphabetically and contains files relating to educational reform programs in Spain administered by the Ford Foundation. Fraenkel lived in Spain from 1970-1974 where he established a field office and worked with Spanish educators and officials to improve advanced training and create opportunities for Spaniards to conduct research in the United States and Europe. The subseries includes general information about these programs, consultants, universities in Spain, fellowship applications, and research applications. The bulk of this subseries is in Spanish.

The Correspondence subseries (1960-1979) is arranged alphabetically and contains correspondence related to Fraenkel's career with the Ford Foundation and with programs sponsored by the Ford Foundation. It was sent by individuals as well as organizations or institutions and is largely professional in nature. The subseries includes several folders of correspondence from American universities and folders from universities throughout Spain. Approximately half of this correspondence is in Spanish.
The Professional series (1940-1981) contains three subseries: Indiana University, Travel and International Involvement, and Professional Associations.

The Indiana University subseries (1940-1964) is arranged alphabetically and contains materials relating to Fraenkel's early career with Indiana University. This includes administrative work, such as university committee involvement and papers related to his position as Assistant to President Herman B Wells. It also contains materials related to his work with international students and international programs at Indiana University.

The Travel and International Involvement subseries (1940-1981) is arranged alphabetically and contains materials from Fraenkel's travels and involvement with international seminars, educational reform programs, and training programs abroad while employed by Indiana University. It also includes materials from his travels within the United States.

The Professional Associations subseries (1940-1962) is arranged alphabetically and contains materials from Fraenkel's involvement with professional associations and conferences. These include the Council on Higher Education in the American Republics (CHEAR), the Indiana Conference of Higher Education, the International Association of Universities (IAU), and the North Central Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools (NCA). Fraenkel traveled to many American universities for the NCA as a member of a committee whose mission was to determine whether or not these schools should be accredited, and materials related to these trips are contained within this subseries.

The Correspondence series (1947-1983) is arranged alphabetically and contains correspondence to and from Fraenkel and the offices where he worked during his career at Indiana University. This series differs from the Correspondence subseries in that it excludes records documenting his work with the Ford Foundation and only contains materials related to his employment with Indiana University.

The Speeches series (1946-1982) is arranged chronologically and contains speeches written or delivered by Fraenkel at various meetings, conferences, colloquia, seminars, and programs around the world. Many of these speeches are about higher education or international education programs. The series also includes a few speeches not written by Fraenkel on similar subjects.
The Subject files series (1943-1969) is arranged alphabetically and contains information on a variety of topics, including Germany in the 1940s and international issues from 1960-1962.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: One box of correspondence from 1971-1974 was sent to the Ford Foundation because it dated from the time of Fraenkel's employment with the Ford Foundation and not during his employment with Indiana University (Accession 9091).
One box of materials relating to the School of Continuing Education was separated for addition to the School of Continuing Studies records (Accession 0996).
One box of materials relating to Paul Klinge's position as Assistant to the President was removed (Accession 0941 Box 10).
Photographs Pulled: 115 photographs were removed from this collection and are housed with the IU Archives Photograph Collection.

There are 7 portraits of political dignitaries or entertainers Fraenkel hung on his office wall during the 1950s and 1960s. These are people Fraenkel met, and later wrote to requesting photographs. Examples include Metropolitan Opera singer Regina Reznik and former United Kingdom Prime Minister Harold Macmillan.

One folder contains 5 photographs of a memorial plaque Peter Fraenkel and his wife Karen purchased in 1974 for installation in Beck Chapel in honor of Herman B Wells's mother, Anna Bernice Harting Wells, who passed away in 1973.

A folder of 53 photographs dated between 1940 and 1960 contains images of Herman B Wells and his mother, dignitaries from the Catholic Church, photographs from a 1957 United Nations meeting with Queen Elizabeth II, photographs with foreign dignitaries from around the world, several portraits of Fraenkel and Wells, autographed portraits of opera singers, and pictures taken during international meetings.

This collection also contains a folder of 22 miscellaneous photographs. Although these photos are undated, the majority of them were likely taken during the 1950s and 1960s, with the exception of a portrait of Peter Fraenkel as a teenager. The photographs in this folder include images of Indiana University administrators, international dignitaries, professional meetings, students at seminars in Peru, Herman B and Anna Wells, picturesque scenes from Brown County, Indiana, and photographs of Peter Fraenkel as a young man.

Other photographs include a group picture from the Wilton Park Conference in England from the early 1970s, a photograph from Fraenkel's consulting assignment in Spain in 1980, 4 photographs from a trip to Mexico City with the International Association of Universities, and 5 photographs from a meeting at the Pontificia Universidad Catolica Del Peru in 1976. There are also 5 undated black and white photographs of the Indiana University Bloomington campus, 3 of which are aerial views, and 12 photographs from a 1961 portfolio from the London-based engineering firm of Brian Colquhoun & Partners displaying examples of their work.
Please contact the Archives Photographs Curator for further information about any of these images.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Additional publications and research materials may be accessed in IUScholarworks
Related photographs may be available in the University Archives Photographs Database
Related information from Peter Fraenkel's tenure with the Ford Foundation is available in the Ford Foundation's archives.

userestrict.head: Usage Restrictions
userestrict.p: The donor(s) of this collection have not transferred their copyrights for the materials to the Trustees of Indiana University. For more information, please contact the Indiana University Archives staff.

The Indiana University Archives respects the intellectual property rights of others and does not claim any copyrights for non-university records, materials in the public domain, or materials for which we do not hold a Deed of Gift. Responsibility for the determination of the copyright status of these materials rests with those persons wishing to reuse the materials. Researchers are responsible for securing permission from copyright owners and any other rights holders for any reuse of these materials that extends beyond fair use or other statutory limitations.

Digital reproductions of archival materials from the Indiana University Archives are made available for noncommercial educational and research purposes only. If you are the copyright holder for any of the digitized materials and have questions about its inclusion on our site, please contact the Indiana University Archivist.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item], Peter A. Fraenkel papers, Collection C492, Indiana University Archives, Bloomington.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: In 2012, the Ford Foundation transferred 6 cubic feet of papers which it found amongst records from Fraenkel's tenure there. The remaining papers were probably found in his IU office upon his retirement.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: Transcripts and student grades were removed. Personal medical information, duplicate items, and blank forms were discarded.
